Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Novel, Robust Process for Thin, Dense Ceramic Coatings
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is aimed at development of a novel, low-cost process for manufacturing environmental barrier coatings (EBCs) for ceramic matrix composites (CMCs) in aviation gas turbines. A key limitation for CMC adoption is the unavailability of inexpensive, truly gas impervious EBCs to provide required CMC engine service life. While novel EBC compositions have been identified, methods of depositing thin, dense gas impervious coatings with these compositions have largely been vapor-based processes that are expensive, inefficient (non-line-of-sight) and slow (low deposition rates). Efforts to utilize low-cost, and fast plasma spray processes, familiar to the turbine industry, have had some success, but still need major improvements. As an enabling technology for CMC adoption into aircraft gas turbines, the proposed EBC processing technology, solution precursor plasma spray, has the potential to fuel wider adoption of CMCs into aviation gas turbines. The EBC market itself, driven by such a wider adoption of CMCs, can grow to over $300 Million by 2025. The efficiency gains due to such wider adoption of CMCs can substantially lower fuel consumption and greenhouse gas emissions by up to 15% in new aircraft.

The intellectual merit of this project is illustrated by the fact that it is the first demonstration of solution precursor plasma spray (SPPS) for EBC processing. The unique ability of the SPPS process to achieve very thin, high-density coatings is driven by the very small splat sizes of the solution-derived particles relative to powder-based processes. The SPPS process offers a route to get coatings similar to what is feasible with vapor based processes, but at much faster coating rates and lower cost. In the SPPS approach, a liquid chemical precursor, containing the desired cations, is atomized into the plasma jet. The injected solution evaporates and the resulting chemicals are pyrolyzed, followed by melting and deposition of targeted oxides as splat of sizes less than 5 microns compared to 30-125 microns with the conventional air plasma spray process. This makes the deposition of thin, dense coatings possible. In Phase I, the feasibility of depositing thin, dense state-of-the art EBC compositions on silicon carbide substrates will be demonstrated, and preliminary durability of the coatings will be demonstrated. The deposition of EBCs with thickness less than 50 micron and with density greater than 95% will be demonstrated.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

This Phase I SBIR project was aimed at developing a unique and novel ceramic materials deposition technology, known as the solution precursor plasma spray (SPPS), that when used to manufacture environmental barrier coatings (EBCs) can enable the use of new materials, improve coating performance,  and allow the possibility of additional functionality. The primary objective of the project was to develop and demonstrate a complete multi-layer EBC system, deposited using the SPPS process, on a ceramic-matrix composite (CMC) substrate that could pass a preliminary durability assessment under high temperature, high humidity and high velocity conditions. The R&D work performed in the project mainly involved (1) development of new materials; (2) development and optimization of the SPPS process to produce promising ceramic coatings with desired microscopic features and (3) design and construction of an integrated test rig for evaluation of durability on a series of complete EBC systems under demanding conditions. At the end of the project, the capability of the SPPS process to produce thin, dense EBC layers was demonstrated, and their durability was also confirmed by subsequent testing. To the best of our knowledge, this was the first time that the SPPS process was applied to silicate-based EBCs and the project has been a success. The project has so far resulted in a provisional patent filing and also attracted the attention of major coating and gas turbine companies.

 

Broader Impacts:

Gas turbine manufacturers worldwide are engaged in a global, high-stakes competition to produce the first ultra-high temperature turbines with >1700 C inlet gas temperatures and unprecedented efficiencies. CMCs are a key enabling technology that has recently gained great momentum in industry acceptance. This project addresses one of the key limitations of CMC adoption – the availability of inexpensive, effective EBCs that allow acceptable CMC engine service life. To overcome the dimensional limitations of ceramic coatings deposited by the conventional powder-based technologies, the solution spray plasma spray (SPPS) process developed in this project is capable of fabricating thin, dense ceramic coatings that will be suitable for multilayer durable EBCs that are still within the practical overall weight and thickness requirements of turbine engine components. Such multilayer SPPS EBCs, in particular, offer added functionalities in dealing with a multitude of threats facing ultra-high temperature turbine engines, such as erosion by foreign objects, and corrosion by water vapor and especially molten glassy deposits.  As an enabling factor for ultra-high temperature capability, gas turbine manufacturers have agreed that new EBC materials and deposition processes are a high priority need. The successful development of the novel SPPS EBC technology through this project will facilitate the maturing of next generation aircraft and industrial turbine systems, and impose a significant positive national and global impact. In addition the technology will allow US turbine manufacturers to meet new stricter environmental regulations being imposed globally. The successful development of advanced EBC-enabled CMC turbine system will also allow US to maintain a technological lead in the global market, and promise increased exports and enhanced US industrial competitiveness.  This project, in part, has led to SST developing deeper commercial engagements with a number of major US coating service companies and turbine engine manufacturers.

  

  

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2018
Modified by: Chen Jiang
